General ML concepts :

  • supervised learning : we are given data and its true labels.

  • unsupervised learning : The training set is not annotated and the system must also learn the classes.

  • loss function : l(y^i,yi)computes an error value between the prediction and the true value. examples :

    • single dimension : ℓ(y^i,yi)=(y^i,yi)2

    • multiple dimensions : ℓ(y^i,yi)=∥y^i−yi∥2

    • L1 loss function : ℓ(y^i,yi)=|y^i−yi|

  • Empirical risk : combination loss function of multiple data-points R({xi},{yi},w)=1N∑i=1Nℓ(y^i,yi)

  • Overfitting : general phenomenon where we get a very low training error , and a large test error. usually happens when the model is too complex.

  • Underfitting : low training and testing error.

I- K-Nearest Neighbors

We want to classify our data in classes. For example our data is in R2 and we have 2 classes (say dogs and cats).

In red we have the decision boundary

1-Nearest Neighbors

Simplest algorithm:

  • Given a new x to be classified, find the nearest neighbor in the training set.

  • Classify the point according to the label of this nearest neighbor.

The result will depend on our choice of distance measure :

Problem : the results may be very sensitive to outliers.

Solution : use multiple neighbors.

 

K-nearest neighbor Classifier:

Improved algorithm:

• Given a new x to be classified, find its k nearest neighbors in the training set.

• Classify the point according to the majority of labels of its k nearest neighbors.

⟹ predict yellow

Key assumption in K-NN :

  • The training set and the test set are drawn from the same statistical distribution. Otherwise, there is no reason for a decision boundary learned on the training set to be useful on the test set.

Overfitting : Sometimes the model overfits : works very well for the training test but not on the test set.

 

A solution maybe to vary k ( increase up to a certain point ).This may increase training error but may at the same time decrease test error.

red : training , green : validation

Model complexity increases when we decrease k.

Cross validation :

  • split training test to a real training set and a validation set.

  • choose k that minimizes error the validation set.

Remember that we cannot use test data in training.

Trouble at the border :

K-NN is prone to misclassifying points in the border.

Unbalanced traning set : ( More reds than blues )

The better represented class is unduly favored.

Data reduction :

  • In K-NN we have to compare the data point to the whole dataset then take k best.

  • Sometimes we do not need the whole dataset.

Condensed Nearest Neighbors :

Let X be the set of training samples and P the set of prototypes:

  • Initialize

  • Repeat :

    1. Look for x in X such that its nearest prototype in P has a different label than itself.

    2. Remove x from X and add it to P.

 

condensed 1NN works well

We only have to search for Nearest neighbor in P. Huge time improvement

Curse of dimensionality :

High dimensional are very dense and so we need a lot of samples to cover them uniformly.

Hopefully most of the time the data we are interesting in leaves on a (small) subspace of the containing space.

Example with MNIST : We do not care about all 28x28 images , but only those who represent numbers.

this is an image that does not intereset us

So we can use dimensionality reduction techniques seen later.

 

II- K-means Clustering :

This is an unsupervised learning algorithm. Group dataset in clusters without having their labels.

  • Cluster k is formed by the points {xi1k,...,xink}

  • μk is the center of gravity of cluster k , μk=1N∑j=1Nxijk,μ∈RD : vectorial mean of elements of the cluster.

  • We want points in the same cluster to be the closest possible to each other ,

    so we want to minimize :

    ∑k=1K∑j=1nk(xijk−μk)2

    • that's a hard problem

We propose the following algorithm that is guaranteed to converge but not to find the optimal solution :

  1. Initialize {μ1,...,μK} randomly if need be.

  2. Until convergence

    1. Assign each point xi to the nearest center μk

    2. Update each center μk given the points assigned to it

The solution does heavily rely on the initialization.

Heuristic for choosing K : choose k where the drop of within cluster distances become less significant.

Inhomogeneous data and normalization :

The Euclidean distance is most appropriate for data with homogeneous dimensions:

  • In the 2D toy data, both dimensions are of commensurate magnitude.

  • In the color image, each dimension represents a color channel and varies in the range [0,255].

In practice, this is not always the case:

  • Different data dimensions may have different magnitudes.

  • They can encode different types of information.

Suppose this is our 13-D data :

we can see that the last dimension have large values , and thus contributes largely to the euclidean distance.

Solution :

  • Scale each dimension by subtracting the smallest value and scaling the result to be between 0 and 1.

  • Use a different metric such as the Manhattan distance we saw earlier.

We will try to favor connectivity rather than compactness :

We will transform our dataset in a graph :

Similar data-points will have strong edges and different data points will have strong edges. this is how we will define similarity : Wij=exp⁡(−∥xi−xj∥2σ2)

W ( on the right in the image below ) will be the similarity matrix of our graph .

let's define a cut in the graph : cut(A,B)=∑i∈A,j∈BWij , be try to find a min cut.

a problem we can encounter is very unbalanced cuts. to balance it we will minimize : where vol(A)=∑i∈Adi

Lots of mathematics later this leads to the following problem :

The solution is then obtained by the eigenvector with the second smallest eigenvalue !

 

III- Linear regression :

Given pairs of elements (xi,yi) and another input x we want to predict y^ that is as close as possible from y.

So we will fit a line parametrized with weights w0,w1 : y=w(0)+w(1) between our points (xi,yi).

 

How to choose the weights ?

The weights must be st that minimize the distance between yi^ and yi (prediction and real data ) where y^i=w(0)+w(1)xi.

So the metric to minimize is 1N∑i=1N(y^i−yi)2 : loss function

In higher dimensions :

  • Our line become a plane.

    example for x∈R2

  • Our input x∈R becomes a vector x∈RD.

  • Our prediction becomes y^=w(0)+w(1)x(1)+w(2)x(2)+…+w(D)x(D)=wT[1x(1)x(2)⋮x(D)]=wTx~

    where x~∈RD+1 is the x extended to account to bias.

  • Weights are w=argmin(1N∑i=1N(xiTw−yi)2) where w∈RD+1 .

  • This is a least squares problem.

     

    Derivates and gradients :

     

    • The gradient ∇wR(w)=[∂R∂w(1)∂R∂w(2)⋮∂R∂w(D)]∈RD

    The derivative vanishes (∇wR(w)=0) at the stationary points:

    • Minima

    • Maxima

    • Saddle points (orange).

Computation of gradient :

  1. Given that R(w) is an average we can focus on : ∇w(xiTw−yi)2

  2. Chain rule :

    1. the function (xiTw−yi)2 has the form f(g(x)) with f(g)=g2 .

    2. the gradient is df(g)dg∇wg(w)

     

  3. ∇wR=1N∑i=1N∂(g2)∂g(xiTw−yi)⋅∂(xiTw−yi)∂w

​ =2N∑i=1N(xiTw−yi)⋅xi

Solution

We will find w∗ by solving the following problem : ∇wR(w∗)=2N∑i=1Nxi(xiTw∗−yi)=0

⟹(∑i=1NxixiT)w∗=∑i=1N(xiyi)

on the left hand side we have XXT and on the right hand side we have a vector matrix multiplication XTy .

where X and y are :

X=[x1Tx2T⋮xNT]=[1x1(1)x1(2)⋯x1(D)1x2(1)x2(2)⋯x2(D)⋮⋮⋮⋮⋮1xN(1)xN(2)⋯xN(D)]∈RD×(D+1) and y=[y1y2⋮yN]∈RN

so we solve :

XTXw∗=XTy⟹w∗=(XTX)−1XTy=X†y

This is a closed form form formula were X† is Moore-Penrose pseudo-inverse.

Model evaluation :

  • Once an ML model is trained, one would typically understand how well it performs on unseen test data.

    • At this stage, the parameters of the model are fixed

    • Recall that the training and testing data must be separated!

  • During this evaluation, one compares the predictions of the model with the true annotations of the test data

  • The evaluation criteria is sometimes the loss function but It can we different:

    • Mean Squared Error : MSE=1Nt∑i=1Nt(y^i−yi)2 (same as loss function)

    • Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) : MSE

    • Mean Absolute Error (MAE) : MAE=1Nt∑i=1Nt|y^i−yi|

    • Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE) : MAPE=1Nt∑i=1Nt|y^i−yiyi|

Interpreting a linear model :

  • One can then look at the coefficient values (i.e., the ) to see the influence of each attribute

  • Warning: The magnitude of a coefficient will depend on the magnitude of the corresponding feature/attribute

    • A coefficient might be very small simply to compensate for the fact that the range of the feature is very large ⟹ we will use normalization.

Multi-output linear regression:

Until now we have only seen regressions with output yi∈R , what if we want a multidimensional output yi∈RC,C>1 .

  • To output multiple values, the linear model cannot just rely on a vector w , because the product wTX yields a single value.

  • therefore we will use a matrix W∈R(D+1)×C and y^i=WTx~i=[w(1)Tw(2)T⋮w(C)T]x~i

  • We can repeat the same reasoning as earlier , y becomes a matrix y =[y1TyT⋮yNT]∈R(N×C)

 

IV- Classification

Problem : Find such that w : • for all or most positive samples wx~>0 • for all or most negative samples wx~<0

Binary classification with the perceptron

Algorithm :

  • Set w1 to 0 .

  • Iteratively, pick a random n

    • if xn correctly classsified , do nothing

    • otherwise wt+1=wt+tnx~n+1.

wt is the weight at iteration t .

This will result in the plane making a series of rotations :

the condition of the theorem says that data are linearly seperable

We minize : E(w)=−∑n=1Nsign(w⋅xn)tn

And... that is a problem because :

We want to be less close from points ( image a diagonal line )

Binary classification with linear regression

Labels to predict are 0 or 1.

Step 1 : Predict value between 0 and 1 with regression

Step2 : Converting continous output to linear

  • The output of the linear model is a continuous value *

    • What we would really like is a discrete output, y={1if wTx~≥0.50otherwise

  • This can be achieved by passing the output of the linear model through a step function.

    • the problem with the above function is that the gradient of the function is non continuous which makes optimization hard.

    • a smooth approximation of the step function , such as the logistic sigmoid function . y^=σ(wTx~)=11+exp⁡(−wTx~)

      sigmoid is amazing because :

      1. infinitely differentiable

      2. derivate easy to compute : ∂σ∂a=σ(1−σ)

     

    Logistic regression

    1. Choose function to minimize.

    2. Find weights that minimize it using gradient descent.

    • likelihood of elements being well labeled p(y|w)=∏i=1Ny^iyi⋅(1−y^i)1−yi

      • if yi^=1 then the term in the product will be 1yi01−yi so 1 if we guess right and 0 if we don't. Same reasoning if y0=0 .

    • Given that this is a product of terms between 0 and 1 , it is hard to maximize , so we will try to minize −ln⁡(probability).

      R(w)=−∑i=1N(yiln⁡(y^i)+(1−yi)ln⁡(1−y^i))

      This is a convex function of w ⟹ easy to optimize.

this is the cross entropy , it can also be rewritten as :

R(w)=−∑i∈positive samplesln⁡(y^i)−∑i∈negative samplesln⁡(1−y^i) . The problem

Multiclass logistic regression

Our approach will be similar :

  • K linear classifiers of the form yk(x)=σ(wkTx) . The i-th classifier answers the question : Is this input in class i ?

  • Assign x to class k if yk(x)>yl(x)∀l≠k

 

Maximizing the margin

The margin : the distance from the closest point of the decision boundary.

The larger the margin , the better.

Signed distance : w~⋅x~∣∣w∣∣∣

To make it unsinged : dn=tn(w~⋅x~n)∣∣w∣∣ , w~′=w~∣∣w∣∣=[w0∣∣w∣∣∣w∣∣w∣∣∣]

 

  • Suppose all points can be classified ∀n,tn(w~n⋅x~n)>=0

  • We want to maximize the closest distance : w~∗=argmaxw~minn(tn⋅(w~⋅xn)∥w∥)

  • We observe that tn(w~⋅x~n)∣∣w∣∣ is invariant to scaling w~ so we can scale it such that for the closest point xm we have tm⋅(w~⋅xm)=1

    • For all others : tn⋅(w~⋅xn)≥1

  • the smallest distance becomes : minndn=minntn(w~⋅xn)∣∣w∣∣=1∣∣w∣∣

    • The new problem is : maximize 1∣∣w∣∣ subject tn⋅(w~⋅xn)≥1

    • very hard

  • Easier equivalent problem :

    w∗=argminw12||w||2subject to ,tn⋅(w~⋅xn)≥1∀n

    • This is a quadratic program, which is a convex problem.

BUT , we are heavily reliant on the fact that ∀n,tn(w~n⋅x~n)≥0 and

In the real world , that is never the case

SVM and Slack variables

tn⋅(w~⋅xn)≥1 is a strict constraint let's relax it tn⋅(w~⋅xn)≥1−ξn.

The higher the ξn is the more we allow the model to misclassify xn

Naive formulation:

w∗=argminw12||w||2subject to ∀n,tn⋅(w¯⋅xn)≥1−ξn and ξn≥0

The model will just choose hight values of ξn and will not learn

Right formulation :

w∗=argmin(w,(ξn))12||w||2+C∑n=1Nξn,subject to∀n,tn⋅(w~⋅xn)≥1−ξn and ξn≥0.

AdaBoost

What if our data is not linearly classifiable ?

We will try to solve this problem we will combine many linear classifiers ( these are "weak" classifiers )

y(x)=α1y1(x)+α2y2(x)+α3y3(x)+…

  • yi are our classifiers

  • αi are our classifier weights

Our algorithm will be iterative and will assign weights wi to points. If a point is misclassified often its weight will be high to prioritize correcting it.

Example : Right points are missclassified ⟹ they will get bigger weights

Algorithm

  1. Initialize wn(1)=1/N

  2. for t in 1,...,N

  3. Find classifiers yt : that minimizes ∑tn≠yt(xn)wnt.

  4. Evaluate: ϵt=∑tn≠yt(xn)wnt∑n=1Nwnt

    αt=log⁡(1−ϵtϵt)

  5. Update weights wnt+1=wntexp⁡(αtI(tn≠yt(xn)))

  6. Result : Y(x)=sign(∑t=1Tαtyt(x))

Important : Classifiers yt should behave better than random.

Feature expansion :

We are always investing classification of non linearly seperable data :

  1. 1-Dimension :

    We can use the following mapping : x→ϕ(x)=[xx2] to map to 2-dimensions

    We see that the result of this mapping is linearly seperable

  2. 2-Dimension : same thing from 2d to 3d becomes

after applying x=[x1x2]→ϕ(x)=[x1x2x12+x22]

  1. Polynomial approximation Another case where we can have better result by expanding our data to a higher dimension is polynomial approximation :

    We cannot nicely approximate the following curve with a line but if we choose a degree 3 polynomial, it becomes possible.

     

    Fitting our data (xn,tn) with polynomial of weights wi

    1. expand our data x→ϕ(x)=[1xx2⋮xM]

    2. Approximate using least squares w∗=argminw∑n(tn−wTϕ(xn))2

    3. Solution : (ΦTΦ)M×Mw∗=ΦTtM×1

    Regularization

    We want to prevent to following quick variations

    To do so , we penalize high weights : w∗=arg⁡minw∥Φw−t∥2+λ2∥w∥2

    • This is known as weight decay because in iterative algorithms it encourages the weight values to decay to zero, unless supported by the data

    • λ will be chosen with cross validation

Let's use this to create non linear boundaries :

Recall normal SVM :

w∗=argmin(w,(ξn))12||w||2+C∑n=1Nξn,subject to∀n,tn⋅(w~⋅xn)≥1−ξn and ξn≥0.

Non linear SVM :

w∗=argmin(w,(ξn))12||w||2+C∑n=1Nξn,subject to∀n,tn⋅(w~⋅ϕ(x)n)≥1−ξn and ξn≥0.

Decision trees

The goal to classify data :

The number of data-points of each class must be the same.

We will build a tree s.t : for any data-point v

  • any node will output true or false

  • if true we go to the right child , if false we go to the other child

  • we stop when we arrive at leaf

Compute pl(c) the proportion of samples in each class c that lands in leaf l .

We have that pl(c)=p(Class=c|Land in leaf l)

If , at test time , our test point v falls into leaf l , we will consider to pl(c) to be the probability that v has label c .

Like AdaBoost we will use multiple weak classifiers as nodes.

At each of these learners we will try to maximize the information gain IG

where :

IG=entropy of parent−(entropy of left child+entropy of right child)

=Q(S)−∑τ∈L,R|Sτ||S|Q(Sτ)

In other words , we want to gain the most information , therefore the children should have to less entropy possible.

When we move from a state of high entropy to low entropy we gain information.

That's our criteria for choosing "weak" learners.

It is also possible to choose multiple decision tree and combine them (random forest).

V-Neural Networks

Let's recap what we have been doing :

  • AdaBoost: Use several hyperplanes.

  • Forests: Use several hyperplanes.

  • SVMs: Map to a higher dimension.

  • NEW Neural Nets: Map to a higher dimension and use lots of hyperplanes.

Neural networks is about repeating logistic regression multiple times

Logistic regression : y(x)=σ(w⋅x+b) and minimize binary cross entropy

Repeating the process multiple times : h=σ(Wx+b) each node has its vector wi of weights and and each layer has its matrix W=[w1w2⋮wH]

 

The

Like logistic regression : we minimize the cross entropy :

E(W1,w2,b1,b2)=1N∑n=1NEn(W1,w2,b1,b2)

2 classes : for sample n

En(W1,w2,b1,b2)=−(tnln⁡(yn)+(1−tn)ln⁡(1−yn))

K classes :

  • pnk=exp⁡(yn[k])∑jexp⁡(yn[j]) : probability of sample n to be in class k

  • En(W1,W2,b1,b2)=−∑tnkln⁡(pnk)

Gradient Descent

We go in the reverse direction of the gradient : The direction of greatest decrease

Iterative process : xτ+1=xτ−η∇f(xτ)

f is the function we want to minimize : here it will be En

wτ+1=wτ−η∑n=1N∇En(wτ)

Stochastic gradient descent :

At each iteration , we don't need to compute the gradient over all the dataset. We just choose a batch random on which we compute the gradient.

Stochastic descent: wτ+1=wτ−η∑n∈Bτ∇En(wτ)

Bτ is the randomly chosen batch at iteration τ

  • Helps computation go fast

  • Prevents local minimum and overfitting (why?)

How to compute gradients ? Backpropagation

Let's consider the last layer : we have : The loss function is a function of the activations of the last layers :

En=Ln(a1,…,aK)

If we want to derivate the loss function wrt to the weights wij we will have to use the chaine rule ( wij i-th weight of of node j )

δEnδwji=δEnδajδajδwji by chain rule

given that aj=∑iwjizi we have that δajδwji=zi

So δEnδwji=δjzi : where δj≡δEnδaj

 

All layers will depend of some δh and some zk , backpropagation is the act of starting from the last layer and computing all δh

We do that in two steps :

  1. Forward pass : compute all activations a : each layer depends on previous layer

  2. Backward pass : compute all δ : each layer depends on following layer that's we it's done backward.

     

Convolutional neural networks

Fully connected neural nets :

The problem of neural networks is their huge number of weights.

This is especially the case when we deal with images.

If we consider a WxH image , we can encode it as a WH dimensional vector.

Drawbacks :

  • huge vector , we will need an NN with a lot of weights.

  • We loose the neighborhood relationship of the points of the image.

We want to have :

  • neighborhood relationships

  • translation invariance : the output of the nn shouldn't change after a translation.

Solution :

We will add some special layers before our fully connected network :

  1. Convolutional layer :

    We take our input image , we create multiple modified versions of it. Each version will capture some type of information. Each version is created by taking the convolution of the image with some filter.

    filters :

    the convolution will naturally decrease the size of the image a little (we cannot convolute pixels on the edge). We can fix this by padding i.e adding zeroes .

  2. Pooling layer :

    Reduces the number of inputs by replacing all activations in a neighborhood by a single one which is a function of the others.

    A common choice is max pooling where we replace a neighborhood by the node with the maximum value of that grid.

The final architecture of the neural network :

ResNet

 

 

UNet

Let's use the road detection problem to illustrate UNets,

given : predict :

This a UNet :

  • Down sampling layer :

    The encoder network acts as the feature extractor and learns an abstract representation of the input image through a sequence of the encoder blocks.

  • Upsampling layer :

    To have the same dimensions as the input function.

VI- Dimentionality reduction

Principle Component Analysis

xi : High dimentional data

yi : Low dimentional data

The transformation will be a linear one : yi=WTxi

We will first normalize the data by shifting them by the mean x¯=1N∑i=1Nxi

yi=WT(xi−x¯)

We will also impose the constraint that W is orthogonal : WTW=I

The challenge is to find the matrix W that maximizes the variance :

var({yi})=1N∑i=1N(yi−y¯)2

The intuition is that if we maximize the variance , we will find the mapping that keeps most variation ie most information.

 

The solution to this problem (optimizating var({yi})) is to choose

W=[w1|w2|⋯|wd] were w1,w2,w3... are the eigen vectors corresponding to the d largest eigen values λ1>λ2>...>λd of the covariance matrix C where C=1N∑i=1N(xi−x¯)(xi−x¯)T

We can go in the other way : from low dimention to high dimention : x^=x¯+Wy

 

 

Limitations :

Things change when we introduce labels (classes).

 

In this example the colored classes are the classes we want achieve.

u1 is the direction in which the projected points have the most variance. So it will be the principal compenent. Data projected on u1 will not be seperable into the two classes red and blue.

Low seperability.

Preservation of classes (LDA)

PCA is unsupervised and thus may not always preserve category information.

What we want :

Mathematically , we want low variance between data points of the same class :

Variance withing clusters : (to minimize later)

EW(w1)=∑c=1C∑i∈c(yi−νc)2 where νc is the mean of class c .

We also still want maximum variance between classes.

Variance between clusters: (to maximize )

EB(w1)=∑c=1CNc(νc−y¯)2

(It helps to think about variance as distance here)

We want to simultaneously :

  • minimize EW(w1)

  • maximize EB(w1)

The solution is still the largest eigen vectors of some matrix.

It is important to note that we pass the labels to LDA (contrary to PCA) and we ask it to preserve them after the reduction of the data.

Non linear dimensionality reduction (Autoencoders)

 

We want to make mappings non linear so they can handle these cases.

For PCA and LDA fe and fd were linear transformations.

The principle behind autoencoders in to learn fe and fd

such that x and fd(fe(x)) are the closest possible. In other word the encoding and decoding operations keep as much information as possible.

We learn these functions with a neural network.

One layer :

z=σe(Wex+be) and x^=σd(Wdz+bd)

where σe and σd are non linearities. We learn We and Wd by minimizing ∑n∥x^n−xn∥2

We can have multiple layers :

and even a CNN (good for dealing with images) :

To encode we use convolution , to reduce the dimensionality we can either use max pooling or set a stride >1 .

To decode we use transposed convolutions (ConvTranspose2d)
